awd_titl_txt: Oregon Experimental Relativity Group: Monitoring, Measuring and Mitigating Environmental Influences on LIGO
awd_abstract_narration:
On February 11, 2016, the era of gravitational wave astronomy began with NSF's Laser Interferometric Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) announcement of the detection of a black hole merger. This first detection led to a Nobel prize and spectacularly confirmed predictions of general relativity, but it also opened a new window on the universe, promising many more discoveries. This award will help make these discoveries by contributing to the monitoring and measuring of environmental influences on the LIGO detectors. By helping improve LIGO’s performance, this research will contribute to human understanding of fundamental aspects of the cosmos, an endeavor that is widely believed to have intrinsic societal benefits. The broad public interest in LIGO discoveries excites interest in STEM, also a societal benefit. 

The awardees will work with LIGO site employees to upgrade and improve the sensor arrays (seismometers, accelerometers, magnetometers, etc.) and the injection equipment (equipment for injecting environmental signals) so that the system can be used for measuring coupling and vetting detections. The awardees will help measure the coupling of the environment to the LIGO detectors as the next observing run (O4) approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Nobel prize-winning detection of gravitational waves from colliding black holes was made possible by LIGO's extreme sensitivity to tiny motions of  "test masses". The gravitational waves have to be distinguished from earthly sources that produce similar tiny motions of the test masses. This project improved LIGO's ability to detect earthly interference with gravitational wave detections.

LIGO is now detecting gravitational waves with such regularity that the identification of earthly influences on a candidate gravitational wave had to be automated. This project improved the automated estimates of the probabilities of earthly influences with more precise estimates of whether the earthly influences overlapped with the gravitational wave. In addition, this project added improved consistency checks. The improvements developed during the period of this grant have been incorporated into the current LIGO detection pipeline, and a paper has been published describing these improvements.

The continued reliable detection of gravitational waves increases our understanding of the universe because we can see things in gravitational waves that can not be seen using telescopes and other electromagnetic wave detectors. Gravitational wave observations will lead to a better understanding of the age and future of the universe, the distribution and development of black holes, and perhaps, unexpected phenomena.

This grant also contributed to the education of several graduate students.
